title: If the universe had no objects in it, how would time be determined? - Quora

response.answer_text: I understand and don’t discount the notion that time is subjective - perceived by humans and probably other sentient species. But, this isn’t something to be certain about at t his point, I believe. There are some objective examples of the passage of time. It is true that most of these involve matter. Most of what we think of as “events” involve matter. Some, however, area a function of energy. It is conceivable that there is a universe configured in such a way that energy is present whereas matter as we know it is not. It is conceivable that scalar fields (just one example) might interact with some aspect of duration (repetition, cyclicality, periodicity, etc.) and that that could be a measure of time. I would, then, also discount the notion that a universe without matter is no universe. There are in fact many conceivable combinations of phenomena that could govern the “space” comprising alternative universes in ways that are very different than our own, even if they do not support (life as we know it).

It wouldn't. Without objects there would be no time. A second could pass or a billion years. It's irrelevant. There are actually 2 types of time. I call them cosmic time and atomic time. Cosmic time is measured by the motion of celestial bodies. The rotation of the earth on it's axis. It's orbit around the sun. Etc. Atomic time is determined by the rate of atomic decay. This second type is variable. It's affected by gravity and velocity. As you can tell though, without objects there would be no time.

Time is the measurement of events in various ways. If there are no objects then there are probably no events to measure. Also what can be there to measure any events? There would have to be some form of an object, like an observer.

The passage of time measured without any other observable matter would be done by mental counting or toe tapping, etc. But the scale or procedure to assess time (compared to how we measure it now) before any matter ever cxisted is not within the ability of mortal man.
